questions.neutral: Did you walk the long way?

hobby.message: Political literature still keeping you up?
Get any ribbon for that antique typewriter yet?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect antique typewriters. They remind me of a time when things were different.
neutral_answer: Took the main road, kept my head down. No reason to linger.
My hobby's nothing special, just fix old things.
Hard to get parts these days, with all the controls.
Last week I couldn't get to the market for supplies.
Walked the usual route, nothing eventful.
I tinker with antique typewriters when I can find the parts.
Harder to track down ribbons lately, checkpoints everywhere.
Feels like anyone carrying old tools stands out now.
Suppose hobbies are for quieter times, really.
Yes, I walked the long way. Fewer questions that direction.
I restore typewriters—keeps my hands and mind steady.
The latest checkpoints make it tough to fetch spare keys.
Last week, I missed out on a rare Olympia ribbon.
Still, I managed to clean and tune an old Remington at home.
Strange, the quiet makes every keystroke seem louder.
Long way tonight, yes. Better to avoid the new patrols.
I collect and restore mechanical typewriters—keeps me tethered to something real.
My last project was a 1938 Olympia. Needed parts I can't get now.
Used to hunt for spares at local shops before BCI flagged half the city.
Since the crackdown, I write my journal by hand again, just to feel safe.
These days, even a typewriter sounds like it might draw attention.
Memory's a fragile thing when you can't leave a trace.
Took the back roads, just in case. You never know who’s watching lately.
I’m one of those relics who collects and fixes old typewriters.
Started decades ago—before all this, it was nostalgia. Now it’s survival.
Last week, my usual market route was blocked by Directorate. No way to buy parts.
I spent hours tuning a stubborn Olympia, trying not to think about the patrols.
That machine’s keys tell stories—a different kind of record, safer than the network.
I handwrite my own notes, too. Hiding them has become half the hobby.
Funny, with everything so tightly managed, preserving these little pieces feels almost subversive.
hobby_answer: Still tuning, when time allows.
Old keys have stories. Not everyone likes old stories these days.
Hard to find parts now. Movement's a problem.
I keep my sessions brief. More patrols near my place, after Halden.
Silence is safer than clatter, lately.
Yes, typewriters still keep me busy.
You'd be surprised who listens for the keys now.
New checkpoints make it harder to fetch ribbons. Supply runs are risky.
Some think mechanical noise is coded talk. Makes simple things feel criminal.
Hobby or habit, it keeps me occupied, at least.
Strange how the system turns memories into suspects.
Still repairing those old typewriters. Bit of an obsession.
Parts used to come easy, now, not so much.
Recent crackdowns made collecting harder. Even tools are questioned.
Noise carries differently when the network's down. Room feels larger, but colder.
Neighbors worry about being overheard. Feels odd, hiding a harmless pastime.
Sometimes I write just to remember my own handwriting.
Strange, how a machine becomes a form of relief.
Still tuning the old machines, yes. They're good company these days.
Restored a Remington Noiseless last week. Quietest one yet.
Since Halden's death, even hobbies get suspicious looks. Lots of new patrols.
Checkpoints made hunting for spare parts impossible. My last trip, I was flagged.
Started using carbon paper, rationing ribbons. Analog habits for digital times.
Writing by hand feels like—resistance, somehow. Funny, isn't it?
Some neighbors think I record Council secrets. I let them wonder.
After all this, the clack of keys means more than words.
That's right, still restoring typewriters. Started as a boy, never stopped.
My Olympia survived the evacuation, barely—lost three keys, found them months later.
After Halden, Directorate's chokehold made my errands near impossible.
I trade old carbons and ribbon spools with a neighbor, off the books.
Checkpoints search for gadgets now. Typewriter looks suspicious in my bag.
Last week, I typed Council notes from memory—no digital trace, just ink and paper.
Feels like warding off the system's noise. Silence outside, but a storm inside.
With BCI faltering, even my hobby feels subversive.
Sometimes, I wonder if these machines are the last honest things left.
